title: South Korean man confesses he is the serial killer behind the murder of 14 women
text:
A South Korean man who confessed to the murder of 14 women including nine victims of a decades-old serial killing case won't face prosecution, police have revealed.

Lee Chun-jae, 56, was identified as a suspect in September after his DNA was found to match samples collected at four of the 10 Hwaseong murders, which took place between 1986 and 1991, the New York Times reported.

The suspect had initially denied involvement in these cases, but he has since confessed to nine of the killings alongside the rape and murder of five other women.

Senior police investigator Ban Gi-soo said on Wednesday that Lee - who is serving a life sentence in Busan for the murder of his sister-in-law in 1994 - confessed to a further 30 rapes or attempted rapes.

Lee Chun-jae (left) was identified as a suspect after his DNA matched samples collected at four of the Hwaseong murder scenes (right, a facial composite sketch of Hwaseong Strangler)

Lee initially denied involvement in these cases, but he has since confessed to nine of the killings (Pictured: Investigators at the scene of a Hwaseong murder in 1993)

Gyeonggi South Provincial Police Agency said the suspect gave a detailed confession and was even able to draw relevant locations on paper, CNN reported.

His statement will now need to be verified, but Lee will not face charges for the murders as the 15-year statute of limitations on the most recent case ran out in 2006.

It will also not be possible for the families of the victims to file a civil lawsuit against him as these cases must be taken up within ten years of the crime.

'Naturally, the police must investigate the crimes', a police official said. 'It is an important case that had prompted questions all over Korea.'

Gyeonggi South Provincial Police Agency said the suspect gave a detailed confession and was even able to draw relevant locations on paper

'The victims and their families had strongly demanded [the truth]. No matter how much time has passed, uncovering what really happened is the reason police exist.'

South Korean police investigated 21,000 individuals and analysed the fingerprints of around 20,000 people after the first Hwaseong victim was found more than 30 years ago.

The victims, who ranged in age from 14 to 71, were all strangled and some of their bodies were mutilated with forks, razors and umbrellas.

The infamous killing case, which inspired the 2003 box office hit Memories of Murder, had since remained unsolved.

But recent advances in DNA technology allowed police to retrieve new samples from evidence, including a victim's underwear, which was then matched with Lee, the Guardian reported.

It is believed the one of the ten Hwaseong murders was carried out by a copycat killer, police said.
